description.narrative: Multi-media programme aiming at increasing youth's participation in economic and political life.

UNDP har insänt projektförslaget "Multi-media Initiative for Youth" till Sida för perioden juli 2016 till September 2018, vilket utgör en andra fas av pågående insats "Klahan9". Insatsen syftar till att öka ungdomars kunskap om arbetsmarknaden och deltagande i det ekonomiska livet genom spridande av kunskap genom massmedier, så som till exempel TV, radio och internet. UNDP har ansvaret för insatsens genomförande och är avtalspartner till Sida. BBC Media Action ingår avtal med UNDP och står för det tekniska kunnandet.
Den totala budgeten för insatsen motsvarar SEK 26 miljoner, varav Sida bidrar med SEK 21 miljoner och UNDP med SEK 5 miljoner (motsvarande växelkursen för USD 600 000, 2016-05-28).

Urban and rural youth (aged 15-30), and especially young women, who are in unemployment or in vulnerable employment have the knowledge, soft skills and the confidence to identify alternative jobs and mobilise support from their influencers.

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.

description.narrative: This concluding assessment draws primarily on the Completion Report, 1 July 2016 - 31 December 2018, which was received in a first draft on 2019-06-28 and later in revised version on 2019-09-05 (ref. UM2016/13504/PHNO/93). The Klahan9 intervention sorts under the broader label of "Multi-media for Youth Initiative" (MYI) in UNDP's system. In the original UNDP project document Klahan9 had two main deliverables: 1) delivery of youth-oriented employment education by establishing media platforms, programmes and community outreach activities; and 2) capacity development for Cambodian youth through capacity strengthening activities with the National Employment Agency (NEA). In the Completion Report this has been collapsed into "urban and rural youth (aged 15-30) and especially young women, who are in unemployment or in vulnerable employment have the knowledge, soft skills and the confidence to identify alternative jobs and mobilize support from their influencers". On 17 December 2019 UNDP explained the discrepancies in the results framework, relating it to the wordings in UNDP Country Programme output, UNDP Global Strategic Plan, and the UNDP Cambodia Country Programme Document, as well as the output for the previous MYI phase where the Loy9 programme was featured (ref. UM2016/13504/PHNO/97). However, during the implementation period the measurement methods of indicators changed as well, which also was covered in the UNDP explanation of 17 December. In the Completion Report of UNDP these changes were not captured or explained and it makes it more challenging to trace revisions to the results framework. In essence, however, set targets and indicatorts have been kept and followed-up on. The explanation provided by UNDP on 17 December 2019 is found adequate. Below summary of results refer to the Completion Report. On the multi-media component (indicator 4) the Klahan9 Facebook page reached 1 million 15-30 year old during the last quarter of 2018. The Klahan9 YouTube channel registered 638,000 views; the Klahan9 website 68,000 and Klahan9 Instagram page reached 17,000 people by December 2018. The TV show, "Dream Station", reached an estimated 1.14 million people in Cambodia. The TV show focuses on how real life problems of young people can be managed and plans for the future made achievable. During the 2016-2018 implementation period, BBCMA found that the number of young radio listeners had dropped from 92 percent in 2013 to 74 percent in 2016 and the trend seemed to be continuing. In December 2016 BBCMA decided to take Klahan9 off radio and instead focus more on the other media platforms. Qualitative data from the project and the Final evaluation indicates that young people exposed to Klahan9 information understand the need for information (indicator 1), feel motivated to make plans about their future (indicator 2), and are more readily applying negotiation techniques to reach their goals - except to their parents (indicator 3), which continues to be a challenge. Outreach activities/trainings (also sorting under indicator 4) reached 300 participants in 2016 and 327 in 2017 in different parts of Cambodia. The Klahan9 Roadshow was conducted 13 times since 2016 and reached close to 9,000 people. Finally, 470 "Klahan9 Ambassadors" were selected and trained to be better placed to share Klahan9 information to family and friends. On the non-media component, the support to the NEA continued and the multimedia capacity of the NEA was thus strengthened through the production of a communication stratey (indicator 5) and successful implementation of the communication strategy (indicator 6). A partnership was as well established with the Young Entrepreneurs Association of Cambodia, which is a private sector umbrella organisation, leading to trainings in entrepreneurship and employment of at least 1,741 youth in four provinces. Efforts were also made to provide employment-related assistance to youth with disabilities, where more than 200 youth with disabilities from 16 provinces were trained on different employment issues. Throughout implementation, Klahan9 strived to showcase the diversity and challenging gender stereotypes in Cambodia. Communication has been formulated in a way to draw the interests of both men and women. Women role models have been given preference when choosing show contributors. Training on financial management and tax regulations was especially targeting persons with disabilities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
